article_title: Rackspace brings managed cloud to mobile health care
article_text:
Rackspace brings managed cloud to mobile health care

Photo: TEDMED A medical student prepares to photograph the inside of someone’s...

Industry players say Medable’s signing on with Rackspace to support the California company’s platform for developing medical applications is just one deal in the emerging health care market for providers of managed cloud.

article_metadata.description: Industry players say Medable’s signing on with Rackspace to support the California company’s platform for developing medical applications is just one deal in the emerging health care market for providers of managed cloud.  “Our customers come to us so they can meet compliance requirements — so we must have the necessary infrastructure, physical security and safeguards in place for our offering,” Medable Chief Technical Officer Tim Smith said in a news release announcing the partnership.  “The mobile health market is set to take off due to the impetus provided by public and private stakeholders across the health care spectrum to modernize and streamline this overburdened sector,” GlobalData said.  [...] there are apps such as Austin-based Visual Health’s DrawMD, which allows doctors to “visually communicate” details about diseases and treatment procedures; Iconic Data Inc.’s SwiftPayMD, which offers mobile recordkeeping and medical billing software; and Qx MD’s MedSpeak, a translator for patients who speak Cantonese.  Longmire said apps developed on the Medable platform “ran the gamut” from complex disease management such as for cardiac transplant patients to research-oriented applications such as one being developed at Stanford to better understand migraines.  John Engates, Rackspace’s chief technology officer, said it was getting increasingly easier to convince health care providers that the cloud actually could be more secure than the traditional data center.  Should patients be worried about the cloud storing a lifelong history of every doctor visit and procedure, all medication or even real-time data such as heart rate and blood glucose?
article_metadata.author.name: By Lynn Brezosky, Staff Writer

Longmire said apps developed on the Medable platform “ran the gamut” from complex disease management such as for cardiac transplant patients to research-oriented applications such as one being developed at Stanford to better understand migraines.  John Engates, Rackspace’s chief technology officer, said it was getting increasingly easier to convince health care providers that the cloud actually could be more secure than the traditional data center.  Should patients be worried about the cloud storing a lifelong history of every doctor visit and procedure, all medication or even real-time data such as heart rate and blood glucose?
